Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy
It is the policy of The C.I. Thornburg Co., Inc. (C.I. Thornburg) Bridgeport, West Virginia facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68.  The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to C.I. Thornburg employees, the public and the environment.  This objective will be accomplished by utilizing general good operating procedures, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers.
C.I. Thornburg management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.

Facility Description
C.I. Thornburg operates an industrial supply distribution center at this location.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders are received, stored and shipped to public and private water and wastewater treatment facilities.
Two chemicals, chlorine and sulfur dioxide, are stored at the facility in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.  The facility stores 100-pound, 150-pound and 2,000-pound cylinders of chlorine, and 150-pound cylinders of sulfur dioxide.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The Bridgeport, West Virginia facility is governed by a set of USEPA regulations that require planning and facility activities intended to prevent a release of hazardous material, or if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize the consequences of a release to the employees of the facility, the public and to the environment.  These regulations include:
?40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention
?40 CFR Part 302, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)
The key concepts in C.I. Thornburg?s release prevention program are employee part

icipation, appropriate maintenance of equipment, and appropriate training of all employees.
Employee participation in the release prevention program is encouraged and supported by C.I. Thornburg management.  Key personnel are responsible for conducting and implementing the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage.
C.I. Thornburg is committed to providing appropriate training to all employees regarding safety procedures.  New employees are provided comprehensive safety training during their initial orientation for the facility.  In addition, C.I. Thornburg conducts regularly scheduled safety training for all employees each year.
 
Five Year Accident History
C.I. Thornburg has not had a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide facility in the past 5 years from the Bridgeport, West Virginia facility that has caused on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

Emergency Response Program
C.I. Thornburg has developed and implemented a program for emergency response at the facility 24 hours per day, seven days per week.  The site specific Emergency Response Plan will be reviewed and updated in January 2007.  The group training will be conducted shortly after the Emergency Response Plan update.  As new employees are hired, individual training will be conducted.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
C.I. Thornburg completes a thorough review of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage areas each time a design change is implemented.  C.I. Thornburg is committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of these areas.
